tossups.question: In a story by this author, the maid Sandra calls the young boy Lionel's father an anti-Semitic slur, which he confuses with a "thing that goes up in the air.” This author of “Down by the Dinghy” wrote a story in which a girl from Whirly Wood, Connecticut is jealous of Sharon Lipschultz. That story, narrated by Sergeant X, is “For (*) Esme, with Love and Squalor.” In another story, the main character tells Sybil Carpenter about the title gluttonous animals before he shoots himself. For 10 points, name this author who wrote about Seymour Glass in “A Perfect Day for Bananafish,” as well as The Catcher in the Rye.

This band used the pseudonym “Passengers” to release a song about the winners of a beauty pageant held in a besieged city titled “Miss Sarajevo.” A song by this band invokes the image of “Broken bottles under children’s feet” after asking “How long must we sing this song?” In another song, this band included the bridge “And you give (*) yourself away.” Harsh guitar is used to depict the horrors of The Troubles in this band’s single “Sunday Bloody Sunday.” For ten points, name this Irish rock band fronted by Bono that included the song “With or Without You” on their album The Joshua Tree.

The Flushing Remonstrance was published in support of this group after Peter Stuyvesant banned their practices. Mary Dyer, one of these people, was executed in 1660 as one of the “Boston martyrs.” A member of this group named John Blunston was an early voice in leading its crusade against slavery. Mary Fisher and Ann Austin, two members of this group, were arrested after preaching about (*) “Inner Light.” These people created a “Holy Experiment” in the colony of Pennsylvania, which was founded by a member of this sect. George Fox founded, for ten points, what nonviolent religious sect of which William Penn was a member?

The partition coefficient measures the ratio of a compound between two of these substances. Though it’s not a functional group, a highly flammable one of these substances that can form solid clathrate hydrates with water is called tetrahydrofuran. One of these substances called DMSO causes a garlic taste when in contact with skin. These substances are termed (*) immiscible if they cannot mix into one another. Acetone is a common organic example of one of these substances. Due to its high polarity, water is known as the “universal” one of these substances. For ten points, identify these substances that dissolve a solute in solution.

In a work about these places in Mettray, the author frequently refers to the concept of the “unequal gaze.” Angela Davis discusses “How Gender Structures” these places in a work that asks whether they are obsolete. An author argued that “the true place for a just man” is one of these locations in order to criticize (*) slavery in the United States. A Michel Foucault work subtitled “The Birth of” these places discusses the panopticon. In Civil Disobedience, Henry David Thoreau describes how he was forced to go to one of these places after refusing to pay a poll tax. Discipline and Punish examines, for ten points, what places that house convicts?
tossups.answer: prisons [accept reasonable equivalents like jails; accept panopticon before mention; accept Are Prisons Obsolete?]
tossups.answer_formatted: prisons [accept reasonable equivalents like jails; accept panopticon before mention; accept Are Prisons Obsolete?]

tossups.question: An Elizabeth Bishop poem about this character that proclaims “None of the books has ever got it right” opens with the line “A new volcano has erupted,” and sets this character “in England.” In one scene, this character spares Ismael’s life and sails away on a fishing raft with Xury. This character may have been based on the life of Pedro Serrano or the marooned privateer (*) Alexander Selkirk. Near the end of the novel in which this character appears, he boards an English ship to flee the Island of Despair, where he had earlier converted his servant Friday to Christianity. For ten points, name this title castaway of a Daniel Defoe novel.

In one of these locations, prehistoric rock art dating back to the Neolithic era was found at Tassili. Numerous shipwrecks led to the coastline of one of these places being named the Skeleton Coast. Lake Makgadikgadi [ma-ka-di-ka-di] was once fed by the Okavango River in one of these features, which is home to the majority of the (*) Herero and San peoples. The Tuareg people often led caravans across one of these features that is found north of the Sahel. Towns in these features are usually established near oases. The Namib, Kalahari, and Sahara are examples of, for ten points, what arid locations?
tossups.answer: deserts [anti-prompt on “caves” before Skeleton Coast by asking “in what general geographic feature is this cave found in?”; accept Kalahari Desert or Sahara Desert or Namib Desert]
tossups.answer_formatted: deserts [anti-prompt on caves” before Skeleton Coast by asking “in what general geographic feature is this cave found in?; accept Kalahari Desert or Sahara Desert or Namib Desert]

tossups.question: In this artist’s only seascape, an apostle vomits over the side of a nearly capsizing boat as Jesus sits calmly on its right. That painting by this artist, The Storm on the Sea of Galilee, was stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in 1990. In another painting by this artist, a woman in red spills a goblet onto herself and the title (*) Babylonian king looks on in horror as a disembodied hand writes in Hebrew on a wall. This artist of Belshazzar’s Feast made heavy use of tenebrism in a painting in which a well-illuminated girl with a chicken in her belt stands among a group of men led by Frans Banninck Cocq. For ten points, name this Dutch artist of The Night Watch.

Ballistic examples of these particles can travel through turbid mediums in a straight line. The differential cross section of these particles when undergoing one process is determined using the Klein-Nishina formula. One of these particles with an energy of 1.022 MeV [M-E-V] can split into an electron and a positron in pair production. These particles lose energy in (*) Compton scattering. These particles can ionize the surface of a metal when their energy is greater than that of the work function. The energy of one of these particles is given by its frequency times Planck’s constant. For ten points, name these massless, chargeless particles that are the quanta of light.
tossups.answer: photons [prompt on light before it is mentioned]

tossups.question: In this city, Allan Lightner caused a tense standoff after attempting to visit an opera house. “Raisin Bombers” were used to deliver candy to this city’s children by Gail Halvorsen, which led to him being nicknamed “Uncle Wiggly Wings.” The Lucius Clay-led Operation Vittles targeted this city. To overcome a Soviet (*) blockade, American and British forces organized an airlift to deliver supplies to this city. A structure in this city contained “Checkpoint Charlie,” which Ronald Reagan told Mikhail Gorbachev to “tear down.” A wall separated the east and west sections of, for ten points, what capital of Germany?
tossups.answer: Berlin [accept East Berlin or West Berlin]

tossups.question: According to tradition, the fates written in the Book of Life are sealed on this day. The term “scapegoat” was derived from the fact that during this holiday, a goat was sent into the wilderness to be sacrificed to Azazel. Many men wear a white robe known as a kittel on this holiday. A long acrostic confession prayer including the Al Cheit is said on this holiday, and services on this holiday close with the (*) Ne’ila prayer. On the eve of this holiday, the Kol Nidre prayer is recited in Aramaic. This holiday is the last of the High Holy Days and occurs ten days after Rosh Hashanah. For ten points, name this Jewish day of atonement generally marked by fasting.

This composer’s Rondo in D for piano and orchestra was written as a substitute finale for his Piano Concerto No. 5. A C-major piano sonata by this composer opens with an Alberti bass in the left hand; that sonata is nicknamed the “sonata facile.” Another solo piano piece by this composer consists of twelve variations on the same melody as (*) “Twinkle Twinkle Little Star.” Due to its similarity to Janissary bands, the third movement of this composer’s Piano Sonata No. 11 is known as the rondo “alla turca.” Johann Peter Saloman nicknamed this composer’s forty-first and final symphony “Jupiter.” For ten points, name this Austrian composer of Eine kleine Nachtmusik.

Cogidubnus was a Roman client king in this modern-day country, where the Roman governor Agricola won the battle of Mons Graupius. The Bridgeness Slab can be found on a structure in this country built by Antoninus Pius. A mosaic depicting a hippocamp was found in a bath complex at Aquae Sulis in this country. Caligula ordered his troops to collect (*) seashells after an aborted attempt to conquer this country. The Battle of Watling Street ended the revolt of the Iceni queen Boudicca in this country. In this country, Hadrian’s Wall marked the northern edge of the Roman Empire. For ten points, name this country governed by the Romans from Londinium.
tossups.answer: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [accept England or Scotland or Britain or Great Britain; prompt on Britannia or Caledonia or Pictavia]
tossups.answer_formatted: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [accept England or Scotland or Britain or Great Britain; prompt on Britannia or Caledonia or Pictavia]
acceptable: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

tossups.question: A piece about translating poetry from this language by Eliot Weinberger and Octavio Paz is titled 19 Ways of Looking at a poet who wrote in this language. A poem in this language compares “bright moonlight” to “frost on the ground.” The author of that poem began another poem in this language with the line “a cup of wine, under the flowering trees.” (*) “Quiet Night Thought” and “Drinking Alone By Moonlight” are written in this language, as are the poems in the collection Three Hundred Tang Poems. Wang Wei and Li Bai wrote in, for ten points, what language, used in the most populous country in the world?
tossups.answer: Chinese [accept Zhongwen or Mandarin or hanyu]

tossups.question: Specific cases of a theorem named for this mathematician were proven by Sophie Germain for her namesake primes. That theorem by this mathematician was proven in its general form using the modularity theorem. Carmichael numbers are counterexamples to this mathematician’s primality test. An equation formulated by this mathematician reduces to the (*) Pythagorean theorem when the exponent is two. Andrew Wiles proved a theorem by this mathematician that a to the n plus b to the n equals c to the n has no integer solutions for n greater than two. For ten points, name this mathematician with namesake “little” and “last” theorems.

This director first included their signature double dolly shot in the film Mo’ Better Blues to give the effect of a character floating. In a film by this director, the camera tracks towards a series of characters who recite strings of racist remarks until a timeout is called by Mr. Señor Love Daddy. In that film, the police kill Radio Raheem during a riot after he plays “Fight the Power” inside (*) Sal’s Pizzeria. In another film by this director, David Duke holds a rally in Colorado Springs, where he meets the undercover cop Ron Stallworth. This director’s movies are known as “joints.” For ten points, name this director of Do The Right Thing and BlacKkKlansman.

In a play in this language, the Fire Chief enters into a party and participates in telling a series of experimental fables with the Smiths and Martins; that work is The Bald Soprano. In another work in this language, Argan tries to marry his daughter to Thomas Diaforius, the nephew of Doctor Purgeon. This language used by Eugene Ionesco was used by another playwright to write about the title (*) hypochondriac in The Imaginary Invalid, as well as a work in which Organ hides under a table to witness the title hypocrite's attempted seduction of his wife Elmire. For ten points, name this language which Moliere used to write Tartuffe under the reign of Louis XIV.

This figure worked with the accountant Johnny Inkslinger and the cook Sourdough Sam. This figure was delivered by five storks at their birth. In another story, this figure makes skates out of bacon in order to grease a flapjack griddle. This man encountered a companion during a period when geese flew backwards, the (*) “Year of the Blue Snow”. Legends associated with this figure were popularized in a promotional pamphlet for the Red River Logging Company. This man’s tears created the Missouri River while he was mourning his dead companion, Babe the Blue Ox. For ten points, name this giant lumberjack of American folklore.

Somali merchants who traded in this commodity established the port of Sofala, while Portuguese settlers searching for it founded the town of Elmina. An object that legendarily descended from the heavens in a cloud of dust to Osei Tutu was made from this material and was owned by the leader of the (*) Ashanti people. A sudden influx of this commodity in Cairo led to a wild devaluation and an ensuing recession. Trans-Saharan trade between salt and this good led to the wealthiness of the Ghana and Mali empires, and this resource appears in the British colonial name for Ghana. For ten points, what precious metal made Mansa Musa the richest man in the world?

The first commercial process used to accomplish this task was the Frank-Caro process. The catalyst primarily responsible for this process requires FeMoco, an iron-molybdenum cofactor. This process is carried out by enzymes encoded by nif genes, and plants provide leghemoglobin for bacteria that perform this process. Free-living azotobacter bacteria and (*) rhizobia living on the root nodules of legume plants carry out this process, which can be achieved artificially via the Haber-Bosch process. For ten points, name this process, in which atmospheric nitrogen is converted to ammonia or other biologically useful forms.
tossups.answer: nitrogen fixation [accept fixation after “nitrogen” is read; prompt on nitrogen cycle; prompt on descriptive answers like forming ammonia]
tossups.answer_formatted: nitrogen fixation [accept fixation after “nitrogen” is read; prompt on nitrogen cycle; prompt on descriptive answers like forming ammonia]

tossups.question: Ninigi married a goddess of flowers instead of a goddess of these things, which explains why humans are so fragile. While dying, Cuchulainn tied himself to one of these things named Clochafarmore. Mithras was born from one of these objects, and one of these things contained the egg from which Sun Wukong sprang. Alviss was turned into one of these things after being tricked by Thor into staying outside until dawn. Horus once (*) painted a wooden boat to look like it was made of this material, and an object that could turn people into one of these objects is found on the aegis of Athena. For ten points, Medusa’s head had the power to turn people into what material?
tossups.answer: stones [accept rocks or boulders or other equivalents]

bonuses.leadin: Despite the best efforts of Simón Bolívar and other revolutionaries, Latin American independence was a bloody and turbulent struggle spanning over 150 years. For ten points each:
answers: Thirty-Three Orientals [or the Treinta y Tres Orientales]
parts: This revolutionary group led by Manuel Oribe and Juan Lavalleja helped win Uruguay’s independence from Brazil. A flag created by this group features three horizontal stripes with the words “freedom or death” on it.

This country’s independence struggle included being part of the Kingdoms of both Guatemala and Mexico. This country was later led by the Sandinistas after the fall of the Somoza dynasty in this country’s capital of Managua.
This country’s independence from Spain and then Colombia was supported by the United States, who later built a canal in this country that connected the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

bonuses.leadin: Entoptic phenomena, such as floaters, are often found in this structure. For ten points each:
answers: vitreous humor [or vitreous body; do not accept or prompt on “aqueous humor”]
parts: Name this clear gel in which retinal blood vessels are suspended. Unlike a similarly named substance, this substance cannot be continuously replenished.
The anterior hyaloid membrane separates the vitreous humor from this structure. Along with the cornea, this structure helps focus light onto the retina.
The vitreous humor, along with the lens, cornea, and retina, are part of this sensory organ. This organ contains cone and rod cells and it enables vision.
answers_formatted: vitreous humor [or vitreous body; do not accept or prompt on "aqueous humor"]

bonuses.leadin: This composer composed an opera that includes the “Chorus of Exiled Palestinians” and the “Chorus of Exiled Jews.” For ten points each:
answers: John Coolidge Adams [do not accept or prompt on “John Luther Adams”]
Richard Milhous Nixon [accept Nixon in China]
parts: Name this composer who based the opera The Death of Klinghoffer on the hijacking of the Achille Lauro. This composer focused on Robert Oppenheimer and the Manhattan Project in Doctor Atomic.

Adams also composed an opera about this president’s visit to China. In the opera, this president, who later resigned in the midst of the Watergate scandal, watches a performance of The Red Detachment of Women.

John Adams won the Pulitzer Prize for music for On The Transmigration of Souls, a piece composed after this event. In the piece, which was commissioned by the New York Philharmonic, several voices read the names of victims of this event.
answers_formatted: John Coolidge Adams [do not accept or prompt on "John Luther Adams"]

bonuses.leadin: In some of these structures, the bimah is a raised platform used during services. For ten points each:
answers: eternal light [accept flame or lamp in place of light, accept sanctuary lamp, accept synonyms for eternal, prompt on lamp, light, or flame alone]
parts: Name these Jewish houses of worship that often serve as gathering places or community centers for congregations.
Most synagogues contain an ark, where copies of this holy text are kept. Along with the Nevi’im and the Ketuvim, this text makes up the Tanakh.

One of these things, meant to symbolize God’s presence, hangs in front of the Torah Ark in synagogues. This thing, which is called ner tamid in Hebrew, may also allude to the menorah at the Temple in Jerusalem.
answers_formatted: eternal light [accept flame or lamp in place of light, or sanctuary lamp, or synonyms for eternal, prompt on lamp, light, or flame alone]
acceptable: synonyms for eternal, prompt on lamp, light,

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about President Obama’s summer reading lists:
parts: Among his 2019 reads, Obama included a box set of works by this late author who wrote about Sethe killing her baby to save her from slavery in her novel Beloved.
Obama’s 2018 list included this author’s novel A House for Mr. Biswas. Another novel by this Trinidadian author takes place in a country led by the “Big Man” and is titled A Bend in the River.
In 2015, Obama read this African-American author’s Between the World and Me. In 2014, this journalist for The Atlantic analyzed housing discrimination in his article “The Case for Reparations”

bonuses.leadin: A part of this piece was later repurposed by its composer to set Cecil Spring Rice’s poem “I Vow to Thee My Country” to music. For ten points each:
answers: Jupiter, The Bringer of Jollity [accept either underlined part; prompt on The Planets]
parts: Name this piece, the fourth in a larger suite that also includes movements subtitled “The Winged Messenger” and “The Mystic.”
This composer included Jupiter as part of the astronomically-inspired suite The Planets. This composer set Walt Whitman’s poetry to music in The Mystic Trumpeter.

This then-director of the New York Philharmonic improvised an additional movement titled “Pluto, the Unpredictable” at the end of the last episode of their televised Young People’s Concerts. This composer included the aria “Glitter and Be Gay” in the operetta Candide.
answers_formatted: Jupiter, The Bringer of Jollity [accept either underlined part; prompt on The Planets]

bonuses.leadin: Shiva sure does do a lot of smiting. For ten points each:
answers: Ganesha [accept Vinayaka or Ganapati; be lenient with vowel stress]
parts: This god, whom Parvati fashioned from clay, had his head cut off by Shiva in a rage. It was then replaced with the head of an elephant, giving this Hindu god of wisdom his most distinctive feature.

When Kama, the god of love, attempted to shoot Shiva with one of his arrows, Shiva incinerated him with this specific body part. In an encounter with Brihaspati and Indra, Shiva used this body part of his to create Jalandhara.

In one aspect, Shiva vanquished Yama, the god of death. As a result, he is sometimes depicted doing this on top of Death. He also performs this action in his aspect Nataraja, which means “Lord of [this action].”
answers_formatted: Ganesha [accept Vinayaka or Ganapati; be lenient with vowel stress]

bonuses.leadin: Depending on the order these data structures are traversed, they can be represented by prefix, infix, or postfix notation. For ten points each:
answers: depth [accept depth-first search; prompt on DFS]
parts: Name these branching data structures, named for its resemblance to a type of plant, whose highest and lowest nodes are called roots and leaves. In the “binary” type of these structures, each parent node has at most 2 children.
The AVL tree is more effective in performing this task than a red-black tree, due to it being self-balancing. In order to perform the binary type of this task, a given list must first be sorted.

For a node in a tree, this value is the distance from the node to the root of the tree. A widely-used algorithm to search trees that fully searches each path of a tree and then backtracks, is known as “this value”-first search.

bonuses.leadin: Dutch farmers were the first Europeans to colonize this present day country, where they were known as Boers or Afrikaners. For ten points each:
answers: concentration camps [prompt on camps; prompt on internment camps]
Horatio Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener [accept Lord Kitchener]
parts: The Second Boer War was fought primarily in what is now this African country. This country’s policy of Apartheid led it to be isolated from the rest of the world.
Emily Hobhouse exposed the high mortality rate and inhumane treatment at these brutal facilities during the Second Boer War. The Fawcett Commission was established to inspect these locations.

This general imprisoned many Boers in concentration camps during the Second Boer War. This general also fought against Mahdists in Sudan and preceded David Lloyd George as War Secretary during World War 1.

bonuses.leadin: This woman is the addressee of many of the works in a 366 poem collection that begins “You who hear the sound, in scattered rhymes” For ten points each:
parts: Name this woman whom an author supposedly met on Good Friday in 1327, the dedicatee of much of Il Canzoniere.
This early Renaissance poet and humanist wrote a collection of his namesake style of sonnets about Laura in Il Canzoniere and wrote the collection On Illustrious Men.
Petrarch described this man in Liber I of On Illustrious Men. This Roman politician is assassinated by members of the Senate on the ides of March in a Shakespeare play.

bonuses.leadin: A recurring joke in one show starring this character consists of his sister-in-law being horrifyingly described but never shown on-screen. For ten points each:
parts: Name this character played by Kelsey Grammer who works as a radio psychiatrist on his namesake 1990s sitcom. On that show, this character frequently responds to his listeners with the catchphrase “I’m listening.”
Frasier Crane first appeared on this earlier show as a patron of the title Boston bar. This show starred Ted Danson as former Red Sox pitcher Sam Malone.
Frasier takes place in this city, which Frasier moves to following the conclusion of Cheers. Frasier’s logo features this city’s skyline, including its iconic Space Needle.

bonuses.leadin: One person with this title wrote the poem “First Dream.” For ten points each:
answers: Archaic Greek [accept ancient Greek, accept modern Greek, accept Ελληνικά [ell-inn-ick-uh]]
parts: Identify this nickname frequently given to both the Mexican author and nun Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz and the author of “Ode to Anactoria” and “Ode to Aphrodite” that alludes to their membership in a group of people that also includes Clio and Terpsichore.

This “Tenth Muse” is the author of “Ode to Aphrodite” and the “Ode to Anactoria.” Some poems by this author, whose sexuality is frequently debated, were collected and translated by Anne Carson in If Not, Winter.
Sappho wrote in this language, as did the authors Pindar and Sophocles. The modern version of this language, which Constantin Cavafy used to write “Ithaka” is spoken in cities like Athens.

bonuses.leadin: Massive demonstrations against pervasive sexual violence and institutional rape culture erupted in this country on International Women’s Day in 2020. For ten points each:
answers: Republic of Chile [accept República de Chile]
subway system [accept rapid transit, prompt on public transportation]
parts: Name this South American country led by Sebastian Piñera. Water rights have been a growing issue between parties living in this country’s Atacama Desert.

A hike in the fares of these services in Santiago sparked protests in Chile in 2019. Other examples of these services include the Paris Métro and the London Underground, the latter of which is known colloquially as the Tube.

These indigenous people and second-largest ethnic group in Chile have increasingly resisted logging and mining operations on their lands. Pope Francis expressed his support for this group while delivering a mass at their capital, Temuco.
answers_formatted: subway system [accept rapid transit, prompt on public transportation]
acceptable: rapid transit, prompt on public transportation

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy:
answers: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance spectroscopy [or NMR spectroscopy]
parts: EPR spectroscopy is often used to identify these substances. These highly reactive substances are formed from the homolytic cleavage of a covalent bond, typically by UV radiation.
EPR spectroscopy is analogous to this other type of spectroscopy, which analyzes J-coupling to identify bond lengths and plots data based on its chemical shift.
To slow down reactions for higher precision, samples in EPR spectroscopy are often contained in a liquid form of this element. This element with atomic number 2 is the lightest noble gas.

bonuses.leadin: This economist criticized the Treaty of Versailles in The Economic Consequences of the Peace. For ten points each:
parts: Name this British economist who advocated the use of government spending to boost the economy in times of recession.

Keynes claimed economic activity was determined by the aggregate form of this quantity. This quantity, which measures the amount of goods consumers are willing and able to purchase, is often contrasted with supply.

Keynes argued that this law, which says that “supply creates its own demand,” is inaccurate. This law, named for a French economist, has been interpreted by some to imply that a general glut cannot occur.

bonuses.leadin: As part of this program, a letter was sent to Martin Luther King encouraging him to commit suicide. For ten points each:
answers: Black Panther Party for Self-Defense [accept Black Panthers]
parts: Name this program that targeted the Communist Party, anti-Vietnam war protesters, and other groups that were deemed “subversive.” William Sullivan led this program, whose existence was revealed after a 1971 break-in at a Pennsylvania office.

COINTELPRO targeted this revolutionary Oakland-based organization, whose members included Fred Hampton and Huey Newton. This organization, which ran the Free Breakfast for Children program, advocated self-defense and gun ownership as part of its leftist, anti-racist ideology.

COINTELPRO was devised by this agency and its longtime leader, J. Edgar Hoover. This agency, which is currently led by Christopher Wray, is responsible for domestic law enforcement on the federal level.

bonuses.leadin: The central figure of this work wears a white shirt and flings his arms out wide. For ten points each:
answers: The Third of May, 1808 [or El tres de Mayo, 1808]
The Disasters of War [or Los Desastres de la guerra]
parts: Name this painting that depicts French soldiers about to execute a man during the Peninsular War. This painting’s companion work depicts an uprising in the Puerta del Sol against French Mamluks.
The Third of May, 1808 was inspired by executions that occurred after an uprising in this city. Goya spent much of the period during the Peninsular War in this Spanish capital.

This set of 82 prints by Goya was likely a protest against the Peninsular War. This collection includes a work titled “This is worse,” which depicts a rebel impaled on a tree, and “They do not know the way,” which shows prisoners tied together in a line with a rope.
answers_formatted: The Third of May, 1808 [or El tres de Mayo, 1808]
The Disasters of War [or Los Desastres de la guerra]

bonuses.leadin: In a story in this collection, Mr. Bartell D’Arcy sings “The Lass of Aughrim.” For ten points each:
parts: Name this collection of short stories that ends with Gabriel Conroy watching snow fall on Michael Furey’s grave. It includes “The Dead” and “Ivy Day in the Committee Room” which are set in this collection’s title city.
Dubliners is a collection by this Irish author, who wrote about one day in the life of Leopold Bloom in Ulysses.

This story from Dubliners concerns a boy’s visit to the title Oriental bazaar to buy a gift for Mangan’s sister. His trip doesn’t come to fruition as the girl selling porcelain is too busy flirting with two men.

bonuses.leadin: The negative gradient of this quantity with respect to position is equal to the electric field. For ten points each:
parts: Name this quantity that represents the work needed to move an electric charge between two points. This scalar quantity is often assumed to be zero far away from a charged source.
The voltage across a resistor is equal to the product of current and resistance by this law. This law’s German namesake also names the SI unit for resistance.
For any circuit component, the amount of this quantity dissipated is given by the voltage difference across the component times the current through it by Joule’s heating law.

bonuses.leadin: This city has seen more than its fair share of sackings since its founding in 482 AD. For ten points each:
answers: tithes [or tithing, accept Church of the Tithes, prompt on taxation, do NOT accept or prompt on “Dormition of the Virgin Mary,” because that is not a practice used to fund the construction of the church]
parts: Identify this capital of Ukraine named for its legendary founder.
In 1240, Kiev was razed by Batu, a grandson of Genghis Khan and founder of this khanate, supposedly named for the color of its tents.

During Batu Khan’s siege of Kiev, a stone church named for this practice was destroyed by the invading forces. The church, which bears the name of this practice, is named after this method, which Vladimir I used to fund the construction of the church.
answers_formatted: tithes [or tithing, accept Church of the Tithes, prompt on taxation, do NOT accept or prompt on “Dormition of the Virgin Mary,” because that is not a practice used to fund the construction of the church]
acceptable: tithing, accept Church of the Tithes, prompt on taxation, do NOT accept
prompt on “Dormition of the Virgin Mary,” because that is not a practice used to fund the construction of the church
